721755f.text:
Mott Street, south from a point between Bayard and Pell Streets, and across the latter to Park Street. In the background, is the R. C. Church of the Transfiguration. Note the non-oriental aspect of this locale. View 1 is the original,
View 2 a photostat positive.
About 1890
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
721755f.folder: Mott Street & Bayard Street, Manhattan, NY

721743f-a.text:
Noott Street, north from Chatham Square, showing the main, thoroughfare thru that Manhattan locality known as "Chinatown". Note the ornamental iron balconies and the oriental signs with a total absence of obvious Asiatic individuals. View 2 is a
photostat copy of the oriminal.
About 1895.
Views 1 and 2
Eucene L. Armbruster
721743f-a.folder: Mott Street & Bayard Street, Manhattan, NY

Noott Street, north from Chatham Square, showing the main, thoroughfare thru that Manhattan locality known as "Chinatown". Note the ornamental iron balconies and the oriental signs with a total absence of obvious Asiatic individuals. View 2 is a
photostat copy of the oriminal.
About 1895.
Views 1 and 2
Eucene L. Armbruster

716612f-a.text:
(1)
Bayard Street, north side, east from but not including Mott Street. This view is taken during the dedication of the Gee How Oak Tong Building (A family brotherhood,) at No. 62 Bayard
Street.
September 3, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.  NNEG 3135
(2)
The same view, from a different angle.
September 3, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

721759f-a.text:
Mott Street  . north from, but not including Chatham Square, to, but not including Bayard Street. Shown at the N.W. corner of Park
Street, is the R.C. Church of the Transfiguration.
About 1926.
Ewing Galloway.
No eproductions.

721760f-b.text:
(1)
Mott Street, north from, but not including Sayard Street. Note Public School No. 108, at Nos. 60-64 Mott Street, which was used for
headquarters of the Welcoming committee.
September 10, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
Neq.w 163

721764f-a.text:
Mott Street, west side, no th from, but not including Bayard, to and
including Canal 8treete.
About 1926.
Ewing Galloway.
phe Federal Yriters' Project of the W.P.A. states on page 426 of its New York Panorama that No. 65 Mott Street has been occupied since 1825 and gives as the authority for that statement, the 'Plumber and Sanitary Engineer' of December 1879. This building sppears in the center of this view, being the third structure from the left with fire escapes thereupon. Note that the roofing cornice has been removed. The tenements to this side of same are of the dumbbell type which originated in 1879 subsequent to the repeal in 1872 of the first tenement housing
law of 1867.
